p:
While there is, at this time, little evidence that SARS-CoV-2 enters the brain parenchyma, there are multiple means by which the virus might be able to do so
75 . Preclinical animal studies (reviewed by Natoli et al.
76 ) report that after intranasal inoculation of SARS‐CoV in transgenic mice that overexpress human ACE2
77 , or MERS-CoV in mice overexpressing human dipeptidyl peptidase 4
78 , SARS‐CoV and MERS-CoV can invade the brain, possibly via transit through the olfactory nerves, to reach CNS nuclei, including thalamus and brainstem; we note, however, that these mice over-express the viral receptors, and these reports do not model normal infection routes.
